answers.answer: As I have not personally reviewed your MRI I cannot give you an accurate medical opinion regarding your particular case.  What I can say is that the location of the lesions or abnormalities that is described in the MRI report that you have provided are NOT typical for MS.  Rather, they are located in areas that are more characteristic for small vessel disease (little tiny blood vessels that become occluded leading to very small strokes) related to diabetes and hypertension.  Based on those findings, it is very unlikely that they represent MS.  I would have to agree with the final sentence of the MRI report.  Hope that helps.

Thank you for your advice.  Althought I am sort of between a rock and a hard place.  If it were MS, it would have been treatable by drugs.  TIA's are much harder to treat. As I am now on blood thinner Plavix + Aspirin, if they continue to happen, there is not much more I can do. I could just slowly loose feeling in various parts of my body, till major things went wrong.  Not an easy thing to live with.

Hi my name is lisa and i just went through something like this with my neroligist, and you canot base you dicison on just the mri on the brain especially if the person is having symptoms. The person needs a spinal mri done to make sure that there is no lesiions on the spine to. I am not trying to make it sound like i am puting your profession down but i have been through so much these last 8 yrs and i have done so much research on ms its not even funny.its a very hard thing to dx ....so i wish who ever this person is alot of luck, if he has any more problems get a spinal mri done.thanks for listeninglisa and GOD BLESS
